Bhargavaea ginsengi is a species of bacteria that was isolated from the rhizosphere (the soil surrounding plant roots) of ginseng plants. It is a Gram-positive, aerobic, and non-spore-forming bacterium. The cells are rod-shaped and motile, with the ability to form coccoid structures under certain environmental conditions.

Phylogenetically, Bhargavaea ginsengi belongs to the phylum Actinobacteria, which is a group of high-G+C content Gram-positive bacteria known for their important roles in various ecological processes, including the degradation of complex organic compounds and the production of various secondary metabolites.

Bhargavaea ginsengi has been found to exhibit plant growth-promoting activities, such as the production of indole-3-acetic acid (IAA), a phytohormone that can stimulate plant growth and development. Additionally, this species has been reported to have the ability to solubilize phosphate, making it potentially beneficial for plant nutrition and soil fertility.

The identification and characterization of Bhargavaea ginsengi contribute to our understanding of the diverse microbial communities associated with ginseng plants and their potential roles in plant-microbe interactions and sustainable agricultural practices.
